articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document, titled "EPHEMERIS" and dated February 1983, features an astronomical photograph. The image depicts a celestial object, likely a nebula or galaxy, characterized by bright cloudy formations set against a starry background, accompanied by smaller clusters.

articles.title: CALENDER
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed calendar of events for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for February and March, including multiple star parties at various locations, Board of Directors meetings, and General Meetings featuring NASA films. Key events highlighted are the preparation for and execution of a multi-night Messier Marathon. Additionally, it contains administrative details for the SJAA's publication 'EPHEMERIS,' including submission guidelines and contact information for the association's officers and board members.

articles.title: BAY AREA ASTRONOMICAL AUCTION
articles.summary: The article announces the 3rd annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, an SJAA-sponsored event scheduled for April 30. It encourages participants to sell their unused astronomical items like telescopes, books, and eyepieces, and invites bargain hunters to bid on a variety of new and used equipment. Proceeds from the auction, held at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, will support the SJAA's amateur astronomy activities.

articles.title: OBSERVE FROM MAUNA KEA
articles.summary: Jack Marling is inviting serious observers and astrophotographers to join him on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, to use the University of Hawaii's 24-inch telescope during the dark moon period of March 8-14, 1983. The invitation includes details on accommodation and transportation costs, with contact information provided for interested individuals.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: The article reviews 1982 comet activity, noting 11 discoveries and recoveries, including one amateur discovery and professional finds by Hartley, as well as the recovery of Halley's Comet. It provides details and viewing prospects for several periodic comets like Tempel-1, Kopff, and Churyumov-Gerasimenko, encouraging current observation. Additionally, it recounts the 1976 discovery of Comet Bradfield by amateur William Bradfield, discussing its visibility.

articles.title: Comet Bradfield (1978c):
articles.summary: Comet Bradfield (1978c) was discovered by William Bradfield on February 4, 1978, marking his seventh comet discovery after 360 hours of searching. Initially, it was too far south to be observed from higher latitudes but was visible to Southern Hemisphere observers for several months. The article provides details on its magnitude, celestial coordinates at discovery, and its path near Omega Centauri.

articles.title: LUNAR ECLIPSE
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland provides a detailed observing report of the December 30, 1982 lunar eclipse from San Jose, California. He focused primarily on occultation timings, setting a personal record, and noted a dark totality (Danjon scale 0) with a blue edge to the advancing shadow but a striking absence of red colors. Despite the cold, he considered it a 'grand spectacle,' sharing some observations with his wife.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: This space program update details the recent death of Apollo 13 astronaut and U.S. Rep.-elect John L. Swigert, alongside ongoing developments in spaceflight. Key news includes a delay for the sixth Space Shuttle flight due to a hydrogen leak, the anticipated uncontrolled reentry of the Russian nuclear-powered satellite Cosmos 1402, and the launch of a military weather satellite. Additionally, the article covers the upcoming launch of the Infrared Astronomical Satellite (IRAS) and outlines NASA's FY'84 budget, which secured funding for a fifth shuttle orbiter and a Venus Radar Mapper, while several other projects faced cuts.

articles.title: EMPLOYMENT POSITION AT LUMICON
articles.summary: Lumicon is seeking a versatile individual for a permanent, full-time position involving a range of administrative and operational tasks including orders, inventory, sales, and record keeping. The role offers a starting salary of $1000 per month and up, depending on experience, with familiarity in astronomy being helpful but not essential. Interested candidates should send their resume to Dr. Jack Marling at Lumicon's Livermore address.

articles.title: WEATHER IN THE BAY AREA
articles.summary: An amateur astronomer details eight years of personal weather records from the San Francisco Bay Area, primarily gathered to aid comet hunting. The author discusses evolving observation methodologies, changes in location from Concord to Loma Prieta, and how the definition of 'clear' versus 'cloudy' nights shifted over time. Despite these variables, the report concludes that ample opportunities for astronomical observation exist by adapting to weather conditions, emphasizing that clear nights are more frequent than cloudy ones.

articles.title: CLOUDY NIGHTS PER MONTH, 1975-1982
articles.summary: This document presents a statistical analysis of cloudy nights per month spanning an eight-year period from 1975 to 1982. It details the average number of cloudy nights, the percentage of cloudy nights, and the minimum and maximum recorded cloudy nights for each month. The data reveals a clear seasonal pattern, with fewer cloudy nights in summer months (June-August) and significantly more during winter and early spring.

articles.title: CLOUDY NIGHTS PER YEAR
articles.summary: This document presents a concise table detailing the number of cloudy nights observed per year from 1975 to 1981, with a total of 1075.5 cloudy nights recorded across these years. The data was compiled by Don Machholz.

articles.title: THE LAST GREAT LUNAR ECLIPSE OF '83
articles.summary: Tom Ahl recounts his experience observing the last great lunar eclipse of 1983 from Iona Prietta with his son, joined later by Bill Cooke and Jeff Horne. Despite clear skies, the observation was significantly hampered by extreme cold and strong winds that rocked their telescopes, preventing successful deep-sky viewing and astrophotography attempts. Ahl details the eclipse's progression and notes a unique 3D effect of stars around the fully eclipsed moon before departing at dawn.

articles.title: MY FAVORITE NON-MESSIER GALAXIES
articles.summary: The article presents a personal selection of 'favorite non-Messier galaxies' that are comparable in brightness and visual appeal to many Messier objects. It highlights their worthiness for observation, providing NGC numbers, brief descriptions, and observing tips for each, while recommending Burnham's for detailed astronomical data.

articles.title: My Favorite Non-Messier Galaxies, continued
articles.summary: This article, 'My Favorite Non-Messier Galaxies, continued,' provides a detailed list of non-Messier deep-sky objects selected based on magnitude, size, or personal favoritism. For each galaxy, the author offers observational notes, descriptions of their appearance, and tips regarding optimal viewing conditions or unique features. The selection includes various types of galaxies, highlighting some as showpieces while noting others require dark skies and larger apertures.

articles.title: My Favorite Non-Messier Galaxies, continued
articles.summary: This article, a continuation of a series, details a list of the author's favorite non-Messier galaxies, providing descriptions of their appearance, observational challenges, and locations. It covers a range of galaxy types, including spirals, ellipticals, and irregulars, and notes their visibility through different telescope sizes and sky conditions. The author shares personal viewing experiences and tips for locating these deep-sky objects.

articles.title: My Favorite Non-Messier Galaxies, continued
articles.summary: This article, a continuation of "My Favorite Non-Messier Galaxies," details observations and characteristics of several NGC galaxies preferred by the author. It provides brief descriptions of each galaxy's appearance, size, brightness, and location, often including personal observing notes or historical context like supernova sightings. The author encourages observers to seek out these often-overlooked celestial objects.

articles.title: SAN JOSE, CA 95153
articles.summary: This document appears to be a postal marking or record originating from San Jose, CA 95153, dated June 11, 1993. It indicates that postage was paid, featuring an image of a 29-cent U.S. postage stamp.
